label: Travel
description: Airlines, hotels, car rentals, cruise lines, OTAs, and travel companies facilitating leisure and business travel, characterized by inventory perishability, extreme price sensitivity, and complex distribution networks.
characteristics: Capital-intensive operations ($80M-$450M per aircraft, $150K-$500K per hotel room)
High distribution costs (GDS fees, OTA commissions = 15-25% of revenue)
Complex revenue management (300+ fare classes, dynamic pricing)
Operational intensity (crew scheduling 15K-60K employees, maintenance requirements)
Loyalty program economics ($20B+ annual frequent flyer revenue)
Regulatory complexity (FAA, DOT, TSA, international aviation authorities)
segments: Legacy Airlines (American, Delta, United, British Airways) - Hub-and-spoke networks, premium cabins, global alliances
Low-Cost Carriers (Southwest, Spirit, Ryanair, EasyJet) - Point-to-point, single aircraft type, ancillary revenue focus
Regional Airlines (SkyWest, Republic, Endeavor) - Operate for mainline carriers, smaller aircraft
Full-Service Hotels (Marriott, Hilton, Hyatt, IHG) - Multiple brands, loyalty programs, franchised/managed properties
Limited-Service Hotels (Hampton, Fairfield, Holiday Inn Express) - Smaller footprint, breakfast focus
Cruise Lines (Carnival, Royal Caribbean, Norwegian) - Floating resorts, complex itineraries, onboard revenue
OTAs (Expedia, Booking.com, Airbnb) - Aggregation model, metasearch, direct booking competition

stats.disruptionRate: 20-30% of flights affected by weather/mechanical issues
stats.loyaltyMembers: 200M+ US frequent flyer members, 150M+ hotel members
